text:
I was having a look at our new Google+ community
where all you Head Squeezers have been sending

in questions to us and I spotted one by Ben
Trendkilla (nice surname by the way) who asked:

''How big would the space station have to
be to be able to see it with the naked eye
and make out its shape during the day?''

Brilliant question Ben, it certainly got me
scratching my head and then reaching for the
calculator.

Now before you guys say "That we can see the
ISS already with the naked eye", when you

look at it in the night's sky and do a #ISSwave,
what you're actually seeing is sunlight reflected
off of the station.

To answer Ben's question though, I'm gonna
put the formula for angular diameter to great

use... but first we need to think about the
human variables...
your eyes!

How do we see with our eyes and then how does
that get put together into a picture by our
brain?

This isn't as simple to understand as say
a digital camera, something that good old
Mr May has already looked into.

For instance, unlike a camera which has well
defined pixels on its censor, the human retina

has on average 5 million cone receptors for
colour vision but then a hundred million rods

which provide contrast and define the sharpness
of the image.

Also your eyes are constantly darting around
all over the place without you even noticing.

Essentially your brain is auto-stitching together
lots of smaller pictures to form one big panorama

that curves around in front of you forming
your field of view roughly 160 by 175 degrees.

And this leads us onto perspective, how big
we see something obviously depends on how

big the thing physically is and how far away
it is as well.

As Father Ted so succinctly put: "These are
small, but the ones out there are far away"

and this has lead to thousands of hilarious
Instagrams of people holding the Eiffel tower

in their hands and even brought Hobbits to
the silver screen, so-called false perspective.

It's clear that the key to perspective though
is angles, because that's how we perceive
how big something is in our field of view.

There's a mathematical expression for this
that we can put to use for Ben's question

and here it is:
The angle 'A' is equal to two times the inverse

tangent of the physical size of the object
'S' divided by two times the distance 'D'
away from us that the object is.
Simple trigonometry!
So let's put it to use on the ISS.
The trouble is... how good is human eyesight?

Or more precisely what is its angular resolution,
the smallest angule that we can see?

Now that's going to vary massively from person
to person, I know people who can't read text
from a few metres away that I can easily.

But even arriving at an average value for
this has caused arguments between scientists
over the years.

The maximum resolution of human vision is
generally thought to be 0.3 arc minutes or

0.005 degrees, but that's in good light for
something that's isn't moving... basically
the best conditions imaginable.

So I'm going to use the slightly larger value
of 4 arc minutes or 0.07 degrees, a value

that at least a couple of experts on angular
resolution have quoted.

The reason I've gone for the larger value
is that the ISS moves very fast, it typically

passes over between 30 seconds and a few minutes
because it orbits the Earth 16 times going

at 22.5 times the speed of sound or 7.7 km
a second for all you metric fans.
OK, it's calculation time.

Now as I mentioned in my previous ISS video
here, the station's altitude varies because

air resistance slows it down causing it to
drop.

At its closest the station is 300km above
us, so combining that with the smallest angle

we can see tells us the ISS needs to be at
least 367m long for us to see it.

That's five times bigger than its actual length
of 72.5m.

Even at five times bigger though, you're not
really going to be able to make out the station.

Thinking in terms of pixels for simplicity,
like the ones making me up right now on whatever
this device is, it's only gonna be one pixel.

You can't see its shape with just one pixel,
it's a dot!

So that got me looking at various different
images of the ISS and playing around with

their size, shrinking them down and seeing
how much you could see... and here they are.

I reckon you need at least 5 pixels of width
from this angle to make out the station's

shape, that means it would have to be 25 times
its current size, or 1.8km wide.
That's huge!

But as I mentioned when debunking the movie
Pacific Rim, multiplying the ISS' dimensions

by 25 means its volume is going to increase
15 and a half thousand times.

Now giving that the station has taken 15 years
to make so far and has cost one hundred billion

dollars, timing those by 15.5 thousand is
quite frankly ridiculous... and that's not

even factoring in the power and atmospheric
drag problems!

With our handy formula though, we can also
ask the question how far away would the ISS

have to be at its current size for us to be
able to see it?

Plugging all the numbers in it works out to
11.9km altitude, which is the same as most

planes fly at so you certainly couldn't call
it the International SPACE Station because

it wouldn't be in space... and it wouldn't
work either.
Oh well.

The beauty of this question though is you
can pose all manner of "how big" or "how far
away" questions.

In fact someone already put the film Elysium
to the test and find out they got their space
station pretty wrong.

But why not work out some others: how far
away would Mars have to be if it looked the
same size as the Moon?

Or how big would an asteroid look as it was
coming towards us?

Have a look in the description, use our handy
calculator, and let us know in the comments
what you find out.
